node.title: Jamie Dimon walks back his quip about China’s Communist Party.
node.alt: Jamie Dimon, the chief of executive of JPMorgan Chase.
node.description: “I regret and should not have made that comment,” the chief executive of JPMorgan Chase said Wednesday.
node.content: ["JPMorgan Chase\u2019s chief executive, Jamie Dimon, expressed remorse on Wednesday for saying the bank would outlast China\u2019s Communist Party.", "\u201cI regret and should not have made that comment,\u201d Mr. Dimon said in a statement. \u201cI was trying to emphasize the strength and longevity of our company.\u201d", "At a Boston College event earlier this week, Mr. Dimon relayed a recent joke he had made comparing the longevity of the multibillion-dollar bank and China\u2019s ruling party. \u201cI made a joke the other day that the Communist Party is celebrating its 100th year,\u201d he said. \u201cSo is JPMorgan. I\u2019d make a bet that we last longer.\u201d", "He added: \u201cI can\u2019t say that in China. They are probably listening anyway.\u201d", "A spokesman for the bank said that Mr. Dimon, who was in Hong Kong last week, \u201cstrongly supports a constructive and detailed economic dialogue with China.\u201d Mr. Dimon \u201cacknowledges he should not speak lightly or disrespectfully about another country or its leadership,\u201d he said.", "Chinese companies that trade their shares in the United States are an important source of revenue for banks. And Chinese authorities are loosening rules to allow U.S. banks to expand their businesses in China.", "In August, JPMorgan got permission from the Chinese government to take full ownership of its investment banking and trading business in the country \u2014 a century after it first opened shop there.", "But banks have to consider the fraught relationship between the United States and China, the world\u2019s second largest economy. China was America\u2019s largest trading partner for goods last year and the third-largest market for exported U.S. goods.", "China has cracked down on tech companies including the ride-hailing giant Didi, the internet powerhouse Tencent and the e-commerce giant Alibaba. Recently, questions have been raised about its response to the star tennis player Peng Shuai\u2019s accusations of sexual assault by a powerful former vice premier.", "[Read more: Wall Street is finally getting access to China. But for how long?]", "In JPMorgan Chase\u2019s recent annual letter in May, Mr. Dimon made note of the country\u2019s rising influence in the global economy. \u201cChina\u2019s leaders believe that America is in decline,\u201d he wrote. \u201cUnfortunately, recently, there is a lot of truth to this.\u201d"]
